message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of acute limb ischemia, with decreased pulses and severe pain. Digital subtraction angiography is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of vascular occlusion. Creatine kinase concentration is useful for detecting muscle damage but not for diagnosing acute limb ischemia. Ankle-brachial index is useful for diagnosing peripheral arterial disease but not for acute limb ischemia. Compartment pressures are useful for diagnosing compartment syndrome but not for acute limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of acute limb ischemia, which suggests a blockage in blood flow. Digital subtraction angiography is the gold standard for making the diagnosis of acute limb ischemia. Creatine kinase concentration is not specific to this diagnosis, and compartment pressures are typically used to diagnose compartment syndrome, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. Ankle-brachial index may be abnormal, but is not the most specific test for diagnosing acute limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of acute limb ischemia and has decreased pulses in the left leg, suggesting a possible arterial occlusion. Digital subtraction angiography is the most definitive test to confirm the diagnosis by directly visualizing the arteries and any blockages. Creatine kinase concentration is not useful in this scenario, as it would be elevated in muscle damage such as rhabdomyolysis, but this is not the main concern. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a screening test that can be used to diagnose peripheral artery disease, but it may not provide enough information in this acute scenario. Compartment pressures are measured in cases of compartment syndrome, which is not the primary concern in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and medical history suggest peripheral arterial disease (PAD), and the decreased pulses in the left leg indicate that further testing is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Digital subtraction angiography is a reliable test for diagnosis of PAD. Creatine kinase concentration is not relevant to the diagnosis of PAD. Ankle-brachial index is a noninvasive test for PAD, but it may be falsely elevated in patients with calcified arteries or falsely low in patients with diabetes or arterial wall stiffness, so it may not be as reliable in this patient. Compartment pressures may be useful in diagnosing compartment syndrome, but this is not the most likely diagnosis given the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest peripheral arterial disease, and the decreased pulses in the left leg support this diagnosis. Digital subtraction angiography is a gold standard method for confirming peripheral arterial disease. Creatine kinase concentration is used for diagnosing muscle damage. Ankle-brachial index can be used to diagnose peripheral arterial disease, but it is not as accurate as digital subtraction angiography. Compartment pressures are used to diagnose compartment syndrome, which is not likely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with acute arterial occlusion, and the decreased pulses and coolness of the left leg suggest peripheral artery disease. Digital subtraction angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing arterial occlusion. Creatine kinase concentration is not relevant to this presentation. Ankle-brachial index may be useful in diagnosing peripheral artery disease, but is not the most useful in this particular case. Compartment pressures are not necessary for diagnosing arterial occlusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms point towards acute limb ischemia, and the decreased pulses suggest inadequate blood flow to the affected limb. Digital subtraction angiography is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis as it allows visualization of the arterial flow and the site of obstruction or stenosis. Creatine kinase concentration measures muscle breakdown and is not useful in diagnosing acute limb ischemia. Ankle-brachial index is also used to assess arterial blood flow, but it is not as sensitive as digital subtraction angiography. Compartment pressures are used to diagnose compartment syndrome, which can occur in acute limb ischemia but is not the primary diagnostic test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest acute limb ischemia, which can be confirmed with digital subtraction angiography, option (B). Creatine kinase concentration is not helpful in diagnosing acute limb ischemia. Ankle-brachial index may be helpful in diagnosing peripheral artery disease, but is not the most appropriate test in this acute setting. Compartment pressures may be elevated in acute limb ischemia, but this is not the primary imaging modality used for confirmation.

Digital subtraction angiography can confirm the diagnosis by visualizing the arterial blockage. Creatine kinase concentration is not relevant in this case. Ankle-brachial index is used to screen for peripheral arterial disease but is not diagnostic for acute limb ischemia. Compartment pressures are used to diagnose compartment syndrome, which is not the likely diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lower extremity arterial disease, and the decreased pulses on the left leg confirm this. Digital subtraction angiography is the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis as it can visualize the arteries and identify any blockages. Creatine kinase concentration is used to diagnose muscle damage and may be elevated, but it would not confirm the diagnosis of lower extremity arterial disease. Ankle-brachial index is a non-invasive test used to diagnose peripheral artery disease, but it is not the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis in this case. Compartment pressures are used to diagnose compartment syndrome, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.
